introduction.p:
Recall that a finite probability space (\Omega, \P) consists of a finite set \Omega and a function \P: \mathcal{P}(\Omega) \rightarrow [0,1] such that
\P(\emptyset) = 0
\P(\Omega) = 1
For A,B \subset \Omega, if A \cap B = \emptyset then \P(A \cup B) = \P(A) + \P(B). \P(A_1 \cup A_2 \cup \cdots \cup A_k) \leq \sum_{i=1}^k \P(A_i) for any events A_1, A_2, \ldots, A_k \subset \Omega.
We refer to \omega \in \Omega as an outcome, and we refer to A \subset \Omega as an event.

The random graph G(n,p) is a probability space where \Omega is the set of all possible graphs on [n]. Note that the vertices are labeled, so the same graph structure appears once for each possible labeling. For every G \in \Omega, with k edges, we have
P(G) = p^k(1-p)^{{n \choose 2} -k}.

li.p:
Find the probabilities of the following events
G has exactly one edge
G is connected
Vertex 1 has degree k for k=0,1,2.

statement.p:
Pick a random graph G \in G(n,p). Explain why the probability that G has exactly m edges is
P(m) = {{n \choose 2} \choose m} p^m (1-p)^{{n \choose 2} - m}.

exercise.title: The Expected Number of Edges in G(n,p)

idx.h: The Expected Number of Edges in G(n,p)

statement.p:
By evaluating the sum, prove that the expected number of edges in G is
\langle m \rangle = \sum_{m = 0}^{{n \choose 2}} m P(m) = {n \choose 2} p.
Hint: Use N={n \choose 2} while you are simplifying to keep you focused on what is important.

Explain why the degree distribution (the fraction of nodes with degree k) for G(n,p) is given by
p_k = {n-1 \choose k} p^k (1-p)^{n-1-k}.
In other words, G(n,p) has a binomial degree distribution. You need to use the following fact: when k is fixed, n is large and p= c/n, we have p_k \approx e^{-c} \frac{c^k}{k!}. So we can approximate the degree distribution of G(n,p) with a Poisson distribution.

exercise.title: The Expected Degree of a Vertex

idx.h: The Expected Degree of a Vertex

statement.p:
Prove that the expected degree of vertex v_k is
\E[\deg(v_k)] = \langle v_k \rangle = (n-1)p.

exercise.title: The Expected Number of Edges in G(n,p), revisited

idx.h: The Expected Number of Edges in G(n,p), Revisited

statement.p:
Use your answer to the previous question and linearity of expectation
\E \left[ \sum_{i=1}^k {X_i}\right] = \sum_{i=1}^k \E \left[ {X_i}\right]
to give an alternate proof that
\langle m \rangle ={n \choose 2} p.
